repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Patch and associated unittests for issue #2508.

Apologies for the overly long wait for this PR - I spent entirely too much time attempting to reverse engineer and brute-force the Cython compilation internals instead of taking the time to understand the various hooks. Feedback appreciated.

comment_data.body: You can add `constant_result=0` here to give it a constant compile time result. (Constant folding, which would normally do this, has already happened at this point.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4749,9 +4749,29 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 analyse_base=False)
 
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start = CondExprNode(
+                self.start.pos,
+                true_val = IntNode(self.start.pos, value = '0'),

comment_data.body:
If `self.start`is non-trivial, reusing the node in more than one place won't work. You have to wrap it in a `ResultRefNode` and the expression during which it will be used in an `EvalWithTempExprNode`. You can find several examples of that in `Optimize.py`.

That also suggests that we should have a test for a slice value that is e.g. a function call. There is probably already a test for that, which also checks for side-effects (to prevent duplicate evaluation).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4749,9 +4749,29 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 analyse_base=False)
 
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start = CondExprNode(
+                self.start.pos,
+                true_val = IntNode(self.start.pos, value = '0'),
+                false_val = self.start,
+                test = PrimaryCmpNode(
+                    self.start.pos,
+                    operand1 = self.start,

comment_data.body: This still needs to be done first, because the `None` check is actually only needed if `self.start.is_pyobject` and/or `self.stop.is_pyobject` respectively, which will be known after analysing their types.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4749,9 +4749,29 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 analyse_base=False)
 
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)

comment_data.body:
This C macro constant needs to be made a C integer explicitly, i.e. add `type=PyrexTypes.c_py_ssize_t_type`. That's also the main reason why travis is unhappy.
The start `IntNode` should get its type automatically.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4749,9 +4749,29 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 analyse_base=False)
 
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start = CondExprNode(
+                self.start.pos,
+                true_val = IntNode(self.start.pos, value = '0'),
+                false_val = self.start,
+                test = PrimaryCmpNode(
+                    self.start.pos,
+                    operand1 = self.start,
+                    operator = 'is',
+                    operand2 = NoneNode(self.start.pos),
+                )
+            ).analyse_types(env)
         if self.stop:
-            self.stop = self.stop.analyse_types(env)
+            self.stop = CondExprNode(
+                self.stop.pos,
+                true_val = IntNode(self.stop.pos, value = 'PY_SSIZE_T_MAX'),

comment_data.body: Added, and I also added `sys.maxsize` as a `constant_result` for the stop index. That value appears to have been set equivalent to `PY_SSIZE_T_MAX` in all versions of CPython 2.7 through 3.7; and is backed by the official Python documentation.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4749,9 +4749,29 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 analyse_base=False)
 
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start = CondExprNode(
+                self.start.pos,
+                true_val = IntNode(self.start.pos, value = '0'),

@@ -4749,9 +4749,29 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 analyse_base=False)
 
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)

comment_data.body: Declaring the `type` explicitly in the constructor worked initially, but the subsequent call to `CondExprNode.analyse_types()` appears to switch the `IntNode`'s `type` back to `py_object_type`. I ultimately ended up adding a call to `coerce_type(PyrexTypes.c_py_ssize_t_type, env)` following the call to `analyse_types()`, which allowed the `type` to persist inside the `IntNode`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4749,9 +4749,29 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 analyse_base=False)
 
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start = CondExprNode(
+                self.start.pos,
+                true_val = IntNode(self.start.pos, value = '0'),
+                false_val = self.start,
+                test = PrimaryCmpNode(
+                    self.start.pos,
+                    operand1 = self.start,
+                    operator = 'is',
+                    operand2 = NoneNode(self.start.pos),
+                )
+            ).analyse_types(env)
         if self.stop:
-            self.stop = self.stop.analyse_types(env)
+            self.stop = CondExprNode(
+                self.stop.pos,
+                true_val = IntNode(self.stop.pos, value = 'PY_SSIZE_T_MAX'),

comment_data.body: Added - I'm not seeing any test errors caused by my lack of use of `EvalWithTempExprNode` / `ResultRefNode` logic, at least from what I can tell. I'll go ahead and add one.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4749,9 +4749,29 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 analyse_base=False)
 
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start = CondExprNode(
+                self.start.pos,
+                true_val = IntNode(self.start.pos, value = '0'),
+                false_val = self.start,
+                test = PrimaryCmpNode(
+                    self.start.pos,
+                    operand1 = self.start,

comment_data.body: It's the return value that we are interested in here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4748,10 +4748,52 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 env, getting=getting, setting=not getting,
                 analyse_base=False)
 
+        from .UtilNodes import EvalWithTempExprNode, ResultRefNode
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start.analyse_types(env)

comment_data.body:
Same thing here, both return the result of the coercion/analysis.
And it should be the other way round: first analyse, then coerce. Coercion makes no sense if we do not know the current type. That also answers your question if the coercion code below is still needed: yes, that's probably still the right place to do it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4748,10 +4748,52 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 env, getting=getting, setting=not getting,
                 analyse_base=False)
 
+        from .UtilNodes import EvalWithTempExprNode, ResultRefNode
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            if self.start.type.is_pyobject:
+                start_ref = ResultRefNode(self.start)
+                start_expr = CondExprNode(
+                    self.start.pos,
+                    true_val = IntNode(
+                        self.start.pos,
+                        value = '0',
+                        constant_result = 0
+                    ),
+                    false_val = start_ref,
+                    test = PrimaryCmpNode(
+                        self.start.pos,
+                        operand1 = start_ref,
+                        operator = 'is',
+                        operand2 = NoneNode(self.start.pos),
+                    )
+                )
+                start_expr.coerce_to(PyrexTypes.c_py_ssize_t_type, env)
+                start_expr.analyse_types(env)

comment_data.body: This depends on the environment in which Cython runs and thus is not a correct assumption about the final value on the system where the extension module will be used.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4748,10 +4748,52 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, getting=True):
                 env, getting=getting, setting=not getting,
                 analyse_base=False)
 
+        from .UtilNodes import EvalWithTempExprNode, ResultRefNode
         if self.start:
-            self.start = self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            self.start.analyse_types(env)
+            if self.start.type.is_pyobject:
+                start_ref = ResultRefNode(self.start)
+                start_expr = CondExprNode(
+                    self.start.pos,
+                    true_val = IntNode(
+                        self.start.pos,
+                        value = '0',
+                        constant_result = 0
+                    ),
+                    false_val = start_ref,
+                    test = PrimaryCmpNode(
+                        self.start.pos,
+                        operand1 = start_ref,
+                        operator = 'is',
+                        operand2 = NoneNode(self.start.pos),
+                    )
+                )
+                start_expr.coerce_to(PyrexTypes.c_py_ssize_t_type, env)
+                start_expr.analyse_types(env)
+                self.start = EvalWithTempExprNode(start_ref, start_expr)
         if self.stop:
-            self.stop = self.stop.analyse_types(env)
+            self.stop.analyse_types(env)
+            if self.stop.type.is_pyobject:
+                stop_ref = ResultRefNode(self.stop)
+                stop_expr = CondExprNode(
+                    self.stop.pos,
+                    true_val = IntNode(
+                        self.stop.pos,
+                        value = 'PY_SSIZE_T_MAX',
+                        # See: github.com/python/cpython/blob/2.7/Python/sysmodule.c#L1446
+                        constant_result = sys.maxsize

comment_data.body: Actually, I'm wondering now if this isn't the right place to add the None-checks, as an else-case. If start and stop are literals, fine. If they are not, we have to check for None (and definitely not coerce to `Py_ssize_t`).

commit.message: Fixing test cases for Python3, added unicode.
Add initial notes from initial debugging.
Reworking slicing unittests to include sliced type - added unsuccessful attempt to resolve issue #2508.
Further experimentation - leaks references, C compilation raises warnings, C++ compilation fails outright.
Move introduction of CondExprNode prior to call to .analyse_types().
Improving slicing logic flow following initial feedback.

Improving slicing logic flow following initial feedback.

commit.message: Protect against values for self.start and self.stop that are non-trivial.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler

title: Support two-element slicing with literal None
